natural problem: I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf?
natural solution: There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n m :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
and h1 : "m = 2"
shows  "fact n div fact m = 60"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n m :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 5"
and h1 : "m = 2"
shows  "fact n div fact m = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $\frac{n!}{m!}$ when $n = 5$ and $m = 2$. The final answer is 60.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: nat
and math_book_copies :: nat
and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 5"
and h1 : "math_book_copies = 2"
and h2 : "arrangements = (fact books) div (fact math_book_copies)"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: nat
and math_book_copies :: nat
and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 5"
and h1 : "math_book_copies = 2"
and h2 : "arrangements = (fact books) div (fact math_book_copies)"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 5 books on a shelf, with 2 of them being copies of the same math book. How many different arrangements can you make with these books? The final answer is 60.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "books 1 = 2"
and h1 : "books 2 = 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>k. k > 2 \<longrightarrow> books k = 0"
and h3 : "sum books {1..5} = 5"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "books 1 = 2"
and h1 : "books 2 = 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>k. k > 2 \<longrightarrow> books k = 0"
and h3 : "sum books {1..5} = 5"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
A library has a series of books with the following characteristics:

- There are 2 copies of book 1.
- There is 1 copy of book 2.
- There are no copies of any other book numbered 3 or higher.

If the sum of all the books from 1 to 5 is 5, how many possible arrangements can be made with these books? The final answer is 60.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: nat and distinct_books :: nat and identical_books :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 5"
and h1 : "distinct_books = 3"
and h2 : "identical_books = 2"
shows  "fact books div fact identical_books = 60"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: nat and distinct_books :: nat and identical_books :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 5"
and h1 : "distinct_books = 3"
and h2 : "identical_books = 2"
shows  "fact books div fact identical_books = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a collection of 5 books, 3 are distinct and 2 are identical. How many ways are there to arrange these 5 books on a shelf? The final answer is 60.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: nat and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 5"
and h1 : "arrangements = fact books div 2"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: nat and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "books = 5"
and h1 : "arrangements = fact books div 2"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many ways are there to arrange 5 books in a row if the order of the books is only considered different when the books are read from left to right? The final answer is 60.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_books identical_books :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_books = 5"
and h1 : "identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "fact num_books = 120"
shows  "120 div (fact identical_books) = 60"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_books identical_books :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_books = 5"
and h1 : "identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "fact num_books = 120"
shows  "120 div (fact identical_books) = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Suppose there are 5 books, 2 of which are identical. If we consider the number of ways to arrange these books, we have 120 different arrangements. What is the number of distinct arrangements when taking into account the identical books? The final answer is 60.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes permutations :: nat
assumes h0 : "permutations = fact 5 div fact 2"
shows  "permutations = 60"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes permutations :: nat
assumes h0 : "permutations = fact 5 div fact 2"
shows  "permutations = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: How many permutations can be formed using the elements of a set of size 5, taking 2 elements at a time? The final answer is 60.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_books :: nat and identical_books :: nat and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_books = 5"
and h1 : "identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "arrangements = fact num_books div fact identical_books"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_books :: nat and identical_books :: nat and arrangements :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_books = 5"
and h1 : "identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "arrangements = fact num_books div fact identical_books"
shows  "arrangements = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a collection of 5 books, 2 of them are identical. How many different ways can the books be arranged on a shelf? The final answer is 60 ways.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes books :: "nat set" and identical_books :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card books = 5"
and h1 : "card identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "identical_books \<subseteq> books"
and h3 : "\<forall> b1 b2. b1 \<in> identical_books \<and> b2 \<in> identical_books \<and> b1 \<noteq> b2 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> perm. perm \<circ> (\<lambda>x. if x = b1 then b2 else x) = perm)"
shows  "\<exists> perms. card perms = 60 \<and> (\<forall> perm \<in> perms. (\<forall>i j. i < j \<and> j < 5 \<longrightarrow> perm i \<noteq> perm j) \<and> (\<forall>i. i < 5 \<longrightarrow> perm i \<in> books))"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes books :: "nat set" and identical_books :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card books = 5"
and h1 : "card identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "identical_books \<subseteq> books"
and h3 : "\<forall> b1 b2. b1 \<in> identical_books \<and> b2 \<in> identical_books \<and> b1 \<noteq> b2 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> perm. perm \<circ> (\<lambda>x. if x = b1 then b2 else x) = perm)"
shows  "\<exists> perms. card perms = 60 \<and> (\<forall> perm \<in> perms. (\<forall>i j. i < j \<and> j < 5 \<longrightarrow> perm i \<noteq> perm j) \<and> (\<forall>i. i < 5 \<longrightarrow> perm i \<in> books))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There are 5 different books and 2 of them are identical. How many different arrangements of the books are there, considering the identical books to be indistinguishable? The final answer is 60.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes num_books :: nat and num_identical_books :: nat and num_ways_to_arrange :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_books = 5"
and h1 : "num_identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "num_ways_to_arrange = fact num_books div fact num_identical_books"
shows  "num_ways_to_arrange = 60"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I have 5 books, two of which are identical copies of the same math book (and all of the rest of the books are different).  In how many ways can I arrange them on a shelf? The final Answer is 60
 ### Proof
 There are $5!$ ways to arrange the books if they are unique, but two are identical so we must divide by $2!$ for an answer of $\dfrac{5!}{2!} = \boxed{60}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes num_books :: nat and num_identical_books :: nat and num_ways_to_arrange :: nat
assumes h0 : "num_books = 5"
and h1 : "num_identical_books = 2"
and h2 : "num_ways_to_arrange = fact num_books div fact num_identical_books"
shows  "num_ways_to_arrange = 60"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In how many ways can you arrange 5 books, 2 of which are identical, on a shelf? The final answer is 60.
